description:
To remove all deadwood and lift low branches to 2m on a group of 7 Elder trees which removes the risk of fallen dead wood and to give clearance of low branches when grass cutting; shown on map as G1

To remove dead stems marked with yellow paint on group of Himalayan Birch trees and to also fell one birch tree within the group which has movement also marked with yellow paint because the branches are dead; shown on map as G2

To remove Ivy on group of mix trees species as Ivy is not good for the trees and fell Cherry Plumb and Hawthorne tree which are in poor condition; Shown on map as G3

To give crown reduction by 2m on Norway Maple tree to balance canopy; Shown on map as T001

To fell down to ground level a young self set Ash tree which has a twin stem, asymmetric canopy and is a poor specimen and overhangs a neighbouring property; Shown on map as T002

To crown reduce canopy of common Beech tree by 1.5m to maintain at sensible height; Show on map as T010

To clear all Ivy from common Beech tree as impeding full inspection; Shown on map as T014

To clear all Ivy from common Beech tree as impeding full inspection; Shown on map as T015

To remove all deadwood and cut away shrubbery around base of tree to create access to trunk on Cherry Plumb tree; Shown on map as T20

To reduce crown of Sycamore tree to previous pruning points by 2m to maintain at suitable height; Shown on map as T021 

To remove approx 2.5m of all epicormic growth on Honey Locust tree and to cut away approx 1m of small branches on young Yew tree which is impeding a full inspection to trunk of tree; Shown on map as T23

To reduce crown of large Robinia tree by 3.5m and remove all Ivy from tree which will encourage new growth and leave tree in a better condition; Shown on map as T024;

To prune out of small co dominant stem on young Cherry tree to encourage tree to grow in a better shape; Shown on map as T026
decision_conditions: The work for which consent is granted shall be carried out to the standards detailed in British Standard Document BS 3998:2010.
To ensure that the work is carried out in accordance with good arboricultural practice.
The work for which consent is granted shall be carried out as an overall reduction, so that the tree's crown remains balanced.
To ensure that the tree's stability is maintained and in the interests of public amenity.
The work for which consent is granted shall be carried out within 2 years from the date of this consent.
To prevent the accumulation of consents.
The applicant is advised that if you wish to carry out further works to the above tree[s] you will need to obtain our further consent.

Anyone who takes, damages or destroys the nest of any wild bird whilst that nest is in use or being built is guilty of an offence under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 and prior to commencing work you should ensure that no nesting birds will be affected.

Anyone who kills, injures or disturbs bats, obstructs access to bat roosts or damages or disturbs bat roosts, even when unoccupied by bats, is guilty of an offence under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981, the Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000 and the Conservation (Natural Habitats, &c.) Regulations 2007. Prior to commencing work you should ensure that no bats or bat roosts would be affected. If it is suspected that a bat or bat roost is likely to be affected by the proposed works, you should consult Natural England (tel. 0845 6003078)

Please note that if the work for which consent is granted is not carried out within 2 years of the date of this letter, it will be necessary to submit a fresh application if it is intended to implement the work.

You should comply with British Standard No. 3998 'Recommendations for Tree Work' a copy of which can be inspected at this office. You are advised that the work should be undertaken by a competent and suitably qualified tree contractor.
application_type_full: Tree works: Trees in conservation areas/subject to TPOs
